185526968.review:
Tales of Zestiria is a good JRPG that blends a traditional fantasy story with action-packed combat. It follows the journey of Sorey, a young shepherd tasked with bringing peace to a world plagued by corruption and malevolent spirits.

The game’s highlight is its fluid combat system, which features seamless transitions between exploration and battles. The fusion of characters into more powerful forms (Armatization) adds a unique twist to the gameplay. The art style and music, especially the soundtrack enhance the experience.

However, the game struggles with a few issues. The story, while heartfelt, can feel generic and predictable at times. The camera during combat can be frustrating, especially in tight spaces. Additionally, the open-world design feels empty in parts, and some side content lacks depth.

Tales of Zestiria is a decent entry in the Tales series, offering enjoyable combat and a charming world, but it doesn’t fully live up to its potential.

Worth playing for series fans or newcomers looking for a traditional JRPG. [b]7.5/10[/b]!

184717517.review: Tales of Zestiria" is a game that left me with mixed feelings. On one hand, the combat system, while somewhat innovative with its fusion of physical and magical attacks, felt clunky and overly complicated at times. The story, steeped in environmental themes and moral dilemmas, seemed to have potential but was bogged down by a convoluted plot and underdeveloped characters. However, despite these criticisms, there were elements I found enjoyable. The world of Glenwood is visually appealing, with vibrant landscapes that make exploration somewhat rewarding. Additionally, the game's soundtrack is a standout, providing an atmospheric backdrop that elevates the overall experience. While it didn't meet the high expectations set by previous entries in the "Tales" series, "Tales of Zestiria" managed to entertain me just enough to not regret the time spent on it.

184707338.review:
Tales games are generally pretty goodf, this one had all of it's innerworkings more or less completed, but didn't apear to bother in polishing it's systems/UIs for gameplay - like at all. 

eg: 3D battlefield that forces 2D engagement (despite actually having the ability to move in the plane), the essential UI systems (gear, skills, purchasing) are all interwoven and overlap, but player must go into completely seperate menu screens to assess what they are doing with each decision. 
Other systems are minimally if at all explained in any way, and seem arbitrary convoluted. 

The story is pretty bland and leans uncomfortably into religious philosophies, with characters that are overly cliche and uninteresting. 

The biggest rub is this offline solo game seems to be designed to incorporate a disgusting level of grinding by default. 

overall, All the hard parts seemed done, but was probably both rushed out the door without polish, as well as evidence of publishers not allowing creatives to have control of their content. 

Buy it if you like tales games and just want to waste time. If you are looking for quality, just pass.

Finally, some of the bosses have a cheap one hit k.o skill, and these are the bosses you will find when returning to weaker areas and dungeon with weaker enemies. There is no balance in this game because one moment, you are fighting weak enemies and in the same exact dungeon, you will encounter boss with super high and super fast attack. This is a very bad game and I can see why this is considered the worst Tales of series.

183792191.review:
É difícil descrever Tales of Zestiria com poucas palavras. Mas, se tivesse que descrever, seria "QUE JOGÃO DA *****!!!"

A história desse jogo é breve e curta demais para a profundidade e personagens vastos que ela tem. Eu queria que cada um deles tivesse uma DLC separada, explicando um pouquinho mais deles, nem que fosse umas 3 horas só de gameplay. Ele te trás um mundo nem tão aberto, mas vasto, com inimigos fortes, armatizações lindas, e o que falar da legenda brasileira? INCRÍVEL. Acho que 90% das screenshots desse jogo é uma frase engraçada dos personagens que as pérolas da legenda PTBR pode proporcionar.

Os gráficos são lindos, porém trazem aquela essência de plot que os JRPGs antigos tem, digno de um Tales of.

Eu pessoalmente conheci Tales of por causa da minha paixão pela série de Atelieres, pegadas totalmente diferentes, mas que te trazem a mesma nostalgia.

Para finalizar um pouco do quão triste o final desse jogo me deixou, uma tristeza de vazio existencial, uma tristeza de "não acredito que já acabou", eu pessoalmente cheguei no final do jogo e nem percebi que, de fato, estava no final do jogo. Deixei de fazer muitas coisas para deixar para depois, e quando vi, o jogo já tinha acabado. Isso não é ruim, mas mostra o quanto ele tem prende, que você nem percebe as horas passarem, não percebe que vivenciou muito e que, agora, está terminando.

É um jogo que te dá o gostinho de rejogar, ele VAI te fazer rejogar.


Conclusão: Comprei só porque achei o Mikleo lindo e acabei conhecendo uma obra prima, e uma série magicamente atraente e magnífica.

100/10
